direction.raw_text: in daylight. At some distance, hoofing down the highway, comes Tom Joad. He wears a new stiff suit of clothes, ill-fitting, and a stiff new cap, which he gradually manages to break down into something comfortable. He comes down the left side of the road, the better to watch the cars that pass him. As he approaches, the scene changes to a roadside short-order RESTAURANT on the right side of the road. From it comes the sound of a phonograph playing a 1939 popular song. In front of the eatery is a huge Diesel truck labeled: OKLAHOMA CITY TRANSPORT COMPANY. The driver, a heavy man with army breeches and high- laced boots, comes out of the restaurant, the screen door slamming behind him. He is chewing on a toothpick. A waitress appears at the door, behind the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see him climbing into the cab of the truck from the right side. Getting behind the wheel, he is releasing the handbrake when Tom appears at the driver's seat window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He indicates a "No Riders" sticker on the windshield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment of hesitation the driver releases the brake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Tom scrunches down on the running board the driver throws the truck into gear and it moves. The scene dissolves to the CAB OF THE TRUCK. It is day, and Tom is seated beside the driver, who is surreptitiously eyeing him, trying to confirm some suspicion--an inspection which Tom ignores at first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cautiously, the driver's eyes drop to Tom's feet. We see TOM'S SHOES. They are prison shoes--new, stiff and bulky. Curiosity is in the eyes of the DRIVER as they shoot a swift glance at Tom. TOM is looking straight ahead, with the dead- pan look that prisoners get when they are trying to conceal something. The DRIVER'S eyes take in Tom's hands and the stiff coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a sigh of relief the driver puts his foot on the brake. The TRUCK stops and Tom gets out. He look at the uneasy driver contemptuously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The driver throws the truck into gear. He doesn't like this at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks indifferently after the truck and then starts on foot down the dirt crossroad. A wind has begun to blow. The scene dissolves to the roadside under a WILLOW TREE in daylight. The wind is still blowing. Sitting on the ground, his back against the tree, Casy, a long, lean man in overalls, blue shirt, and one sneaker, is fixing something on the other dirty sneaker. To the tune of "Yes, Sir, That's My Baby" he is absent-mindedly singing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carrying his coat under his arm, TOM wipes his face with his cap as he cuts off the road to acknowledge the greeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops, grateful for the momentary relief of the shade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pause at the edge of the shade, squint up at the sky, and then move off. The scene dissolves to the SURFACE OF A DIRT ROAD by daylight. Leaves are scuttling across it. The top soil begins to fly up. It is not a hard wind as yet, but it is steady and persistent. Tom's and Casy's feet walk into sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, holding his cap on his head with his hand, looks up... The TOPS OF THE TREES are bending before the wind. TOM AND CASY continue walking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you be back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Couple a weeks. Don't do nothin' you wouldn't want me to hear about!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about a lift, mister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't you see that sticker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I see it. But a good guy don't pay no attention to what some heel makes him stick on his truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scrunch down on the running board till we get around the bend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goin' far?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Just a few miles. I'd a walked her if my dogs wasn't pooped out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lookin' for a job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, my old man got a place, forty acres. He's a sharecropper, but we been there a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a curious glance) Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been doin' a job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I seen your hands. You been swinging a pick or a sledge--that shines up your hands. I notice little things like that all the time. (After a pause) Got a trade?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (evenly) Why don't you get to it, buddy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uneasily) Get to what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what I mean. You been givin' me a goin' over ever since I got in. Whyn't you go on and ask me where I been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't stick my nose in nobody's business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naw--not much!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little frightened) I stay in my own yard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without emotion) Listen. That big nose of yours been goin' over me like a sheep in a vegetable patch. But I ain't keepin' it a secret. I been in the penitentiary. Been there four years. Like to know anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't got to get sore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) Go ahead. Ask me anything you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't mean nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me neither. I'm just tryin' to get along without shovin' anybody around, that's all. (After a pause) See that road up ahead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's where I get off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're about to bust to know what I done, ain't you?  Well, I ain't a guy to let you down. (Confidentially) Homicide!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never asked you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as the truck moves away) Sure, but you'd a throwed a fit if I hadn't tol' you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmmmm he's my saviour. Mmmmm my saviour, Mmmmmmmmmm my saviour now. (Looking up as Tom comes down the road) Howdy, friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Howdy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, ain't you young Tom Joad--ol' Tom's boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Yeah. On my way home now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I do declare! (Grinning) I baptized you, son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring) Why, you're the preacher!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *Used* to be. Not no more. I lost the call. (Reminiscently) But boy, I sure *used* to have it! I'd get an irrigation ditch so squirmin' full of repented sinners I pretty near *drowned* half of 'em! (Sighing) But not no more. I lost the sperit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a grin) Pa always said you was never cut out to be a preacher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got nothin' to preach about no more--that's all. I ain't so sure o' things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you should a got yourself a wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head sadly) At my meetin's I used to get the girls glory-shoutin' till they about passed out. Then, I'd go to comfort 'em--and always end up by lovin' 'em. I'd feel bad, an' pray, an' pray, but it didn't do no good. Next time, do it again. I figgered there just wasn't no hope for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never let one go by me when I could catch her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you wasn't a preacher. A girl was just a girl to you. But to me they was holy vessels. I was savin' their souls. (Fervently) I ast myself--what *is* this call, the Holy Sperit? Maybe *that's* love. Why, I love everybody so much I'm fit to bust sometimes!  So maybe there ain't no sin an' there ain't no virtue. There's just what people do. Some things folks do is nice, and some ain't so nice. But that's as far as any man's got a right to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment, figuring there is no percentage in continuing this philosophical discussion, pulls out a flask, which he extends) Have a little snort?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding the flask) Course I'll say grace if somebody sets out the food-- (shaking his head) --but my heart ain't in it. (He takes a long pull) Nice drinkin' liquor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ought to be. That's fact'ry liquor. Cost me a buck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing back the flask) Been out travelin' around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you hear? It was in the papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I never. What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been in the penitentiary for four years. (He drinks)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me for asking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't mind any more. I'd do what I done again. I killed a guy at a dance. We was drunk. He got a knife in me and I laid him out with a shovel. Knocked his head plumb to squash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you ain't ashamed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) He had a knife in me. That's why they only gave me seven years. Got out in four--parole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't you seen your folks since then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting on his coat) No, but I aim to before sundown. Gettin' kind of excited about it, too. Which way you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting on his sneaker) It don't matter. Ever since I lost the sperit it looks like I just as soon go one way as the other. (Rising) I'll go your way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe Ma'll have pork for supper. I ain't had pork but four times in four years--every Christmas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be glad to see you pa. Last time I seen him was at a baptizin', an' he had one a the bigges' doses of the Holy Sperit I ever seen. He go to jumpin' over bushes, howlin' like a dog-wolf in moon-time. Fin'ly he picks hisself out a bush big as a piana an' he let out a squawk an' took a run at that bush. Well, sir, he cleared her but he bust his leg snap in two. They was a travellin' dentist there and he set her, an' I give her a prayin' over, but they wasn't no more Holy Sperit in your pa after that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worriedly) Lissen. This wind's fixin't to *do* somepin'!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shore it is. It always is, this time a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it fur?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still looking back) Just around that next bend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: are almost being blown along and dust is rising from the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The JOAD CABIN is an ancient, bleak, sway-backed building. There is neither sign of life or habitation about it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (lifting his voice above the wind) Your granma was a great one, too. The third time she got religion she go it so powerful she knocked down a full-growed deacon with her fist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing ahead) That's our place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking back) And it ain't any too close, either! We better run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: like a black wall, rises into the sky, moving forward. TOM AND CASY are running, but looking back over their shoulders as the DUST STORM nears. Dust rises from the ground to join and thicken the black wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are seen racing down the road to the cabin, the wind whipping up the dust. The two men smack open the door and slam it shut after them. The screen begins to grow dark as the storm sweeps over the land. It becomes black. In THE CABIN, it is black too, but the sound is different. In addition to the sound of the wind there is the soft hissing of sand against the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Presently, after shuffling about, he has found them and lights one. He holds it up, lighting the room. A couple of wooden boxes are on the floor, a few miserable discarded things, and that's all. Tom's eyes are bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the floor he picks up a woman's high button shoe, curled up at the toe and broken over the instep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dropping the shoe, he picks up a battered felt hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dropping the hat, he moves with the candle toward the door to the back, the only other room of the cabin. He stands in the doorway, holding the candle high. In the BACK ROOM the scene moves from Tom at the door across the room to the shadows, where a skinny little man sits motionless, wide-eyed, staring at Tom. His name is Muley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muley does not reply. He is looking up at Casy as he enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ma?... Pa?... Ain't nobody here? (After a long silence) Somepin's happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a match?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was some pieces of candle always on a shelf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're all gone--or dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They never wrote you nothing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. They wasn't people to write.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This was Ma's. Had 'em for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This used to be mine. I give it to Grampa when I went away. (To Casy) You reckon they could be dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never heard nothin' about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (entering) Muley! Where's my folks, Muley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dully) They gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) I know that! But *where* they gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Casy) This is Muley Graves. (To Muley) You remember the preacher, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't no preacher anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) All right, you remember the *man* then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Glad to see you again. Glad to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Now where is my folks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gone-- (hastily) --over to your Uncle John's. The whole crowd of 'em, two weeks ago. But they can't stay there either, because John's got *his* notice to get off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) But what's happened?  How come they got to get off? We been here fifty years--same place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever'body got to get off. Ever'body leavin', goin' to California. My folks, your folks, ever'body's folks. (After a pause) Ever'body but me. I ain't gettin' off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But who done it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen! (Impatiently Tom listens to the storm) That's some of what done it--the dusters. Started it, anyway. Blowin' like this, year after year--blowin' the land away, blowin' the crops away, blowin' us away now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Are you crazy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) Some say I am. (After a pause) You want to hear what happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I asked you, ain't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is seen at close range. Not actually crazy, Muley is a little touched. His eyes rove upward as he listens to the sound of the storm, the sough of the wind and the soft hiss of the sand. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to MULEY'S DOORYARD. It is a soft spring day, with the peaceful sounds of the country. Seated in a three-year-old touring car is THE MAN, a city man with a collar and tie. He hates to do what he is doing and this makes him gruff and curt, to hide his misgivings. Squatted beside the car are Muley, his son-in-law, and a half-grown son. At a respectful distance stand Muley's wife, his daughter, with a baby in her arms, and a small barefooted girl, watching worriedly. The men soberly trace marks on the ground with small sticks. A hound dog sniffs at the automobile wheels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muley stands in anger. The two younger men pattern after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to the BACK ROOM. The sound of the storm is heard again as Tom and Casy watch Muley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see MULEY at close range.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to a MONTAGE OF TRACTORS: tractors looming over hillocks, flattening fences, through gullies, their drivers looking like robots, with goggles, dust masks over mouth and nose--one after the other, crossing and recrossing as if to convey the impression that this was an invasion of machine-men from some other world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to MULEY'S FARM. We see the backs of Muley and the two younger men standing shoulder to shoulder watching a lumbering tractor headed straight toward them. It is at some distance. Muley holds a shotgun. His son has a baling hook. The son-in-law has a two-by-four. Behind them is their cabin. Frightened and huddled together are the women and children. The roar of the tractor comes closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TRACTOR continues to lumber along, its driver goggled and black of face where his dust mask doesn't cover. MULEY lifts his shotgun to his shoulder, and aims.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TRACTOR stops. The driver takes off his goggles and dust mask. Like the others he's a country boy. His face is sullen. Muley is lowering his shotgun. There is a surprise in his face as he recognizes the driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves forward, followed by his son and son-in-law in the TRACTOR. Davis is wiping his face as they walk toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see THE WOMENFOLKS. A small girl pulls her mother's dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back to the TRACTOR AND THE MEN:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the tractor roars into slow motion again... We see the HOUSE AND TRACTOR. The womenfolks scamper out of the way as the tractor heads for a corner of the house. It goes over a ramshackle fence and then a feeble little flower bed. Muley and the two younger men walk along. Breathing hard, frightened and desperate, Muley is shouting warnings at Davis, but the roar of the tractor drowns his voice. The dog barks excitedly, snarling at the tractor. THE WOMENFOLKS stand watching, terrified but dead pan, until a cry bursts from Muley's wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little girl begins to whimper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TRACTOR moves across the yard, nosing a chair out of the way, and with a rending of boards hits a corner of the house, knocking a part of the foundation away. The corner of the house sinks. MULEY lifts his shotgun, aims it, holds it, and then slowly lowers it. As he stands looking at what has happened his shoulders sag. He seems almost to shrink. The scene dissolves to MULEY, once more in the back room of Tom's old home, as the sound of the storm continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom rises in his agitation and bewilderment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks down at Muley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are dull on the floor. The sound of the dust storm continues strongly. The scene dissolves to the EXTERIOR OF THE CABIN at night. It is several hours later and the sound of the storm has faded out. Now all is silence as first Tom, then Casy, and finally Muley steps out of the cabin and looks around. There is still a slight fog of dust in the air, and clouds of powderlike dust shoot up around their feet. All three men have wet rags tied over their mouths and noses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The way it happens--the way it happened to me--the man come one day...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fact of the matter, Muley, after what them dusters done to the land, the tenant system don't work no more. It don't even break even, much less show a profit. One man on a tractor can handle twelve or fourteen of these places. You just pay him a wage and take *all* the crop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But we couldn't *do* on any less'n what our share is now. (Looking around) The chillun ain't gettin' enough to eat as it is, and they're so ragged we'd be shamed if ever'body else's chillun wasn't the same way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritably) I can't help that. All I know is I got my orders. They told me to tell you you got to get off, and that's what I'm telling you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean get off my own land?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now don't go blaming me. It ain't *my* fault.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whose fault is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know who owns the land--the Shawnee Land and Cattle Company.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's the Shawnee Land and Cattle Comp'ny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't nobody. It's a company.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They got a pres'dent, ain't they? They got somebody that knows what a shotgun's for, ain't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it ain't *his* fault, because the *bank* tells him what to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) All right. Where's the bank?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fretfully) Tulsa. But what's the use of picking on him? He ain't anything but the manager, and half crazy hisself, trying to keep up with his orders from the east!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) Then who *do* we shoot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stepping on the starter) Brother, I don't know. If I did I'd tell you. But I just don't know *who's* to blame!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Well, I'm right here to tell you, mister, ain't *nobody* going to push me off *my* land! Grampa took up this land seventy years ago. My pa was born here. We was *all* born on it, and some of us got killed on it, and some died on it. And that's what makes it ourn--bein' born on it, and workin' it, and dyin' on it--and not no piece of paper with writin' on it! So just come on and try to push me off!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without emotion) They come. They come and pushed me off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They come with the cats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The cats--the caterpillar tractors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And for ever' one of 'em ten-fifteen families gets throwed outa their homes--one hundred folks with no place to live but on the road. The Rances, the Perrys, the Peterses, the Joadses--one after another they got throwed out. Half the folks you and me know--throwed right out into the road. The one that got me come a month ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) You come any closer and I'm gonna blow you right outa that cat! (He lifts his shotgun)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *tol'* you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, you're Joe Davis's boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like nobody drawin' a bead on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what are you doin' this kind a thing for--against your own people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For three dollars a day, that's what I'm doin' it for. I got two little kids. I got a wife and my wife's mother. Them people got to eat. Fust and on'y thing I got to think about is my own folks. What happens to other folks is their lookout.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But this is *my land*, son. Don't you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting his goggles back on) *Used* to be your land. B'longs to the comp'ny now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's he fixin' to do, ma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hush!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Have it your own way, son, but just as sure as you touch my house with that cat I'm gonna blow you plumb to kingdom come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (contemptuously) You ain't gonna blow nobody nowhere. First place, you'd get hung and you know it. For another, it wouldn't be two days before they'd have another guy here to take my place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't! Please don't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm tellin' you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dully) What was the use. He was right. There wasn't a thing in the world I could do about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) But it don't seem possible--kicked off like that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The rest of my fambly set out for the west--there wasn't nothin' to eat--but I couldn't leave. Somepin' wouldn't let me. So now I just wander around. Sleep wherever I am. I used to tell myself I was lookin' out for things, so when they come back ever'thing would be all right. But I knowed that wan't true. There ain't nothin' to look out for. And ain't nobody comin' back. They're gone-- and me, I'm just an 'ol graveyard ghost--that's all in the world I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I'm touched.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sympathetically) No. You're lonely--but you ain't touched.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It don't matter. If I'm touched, I'm touched, and that's all there is to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still unable to grasp it all) What I can't understand is my folks takin' it! Like ma! I seen her nearly beat a peddler to death with a live chicken. She aimed to go for him with an ax she had in the other hand but she got mixed up and forgot which hand was which and when she got through with that peddler all she had left was two chicken legs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a plain 'ol graveyard ghost, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's settlin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you figger to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hard to say. Stay here till mornin' an' then go on over to Uncle John's, I reckon. After that I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing Tom) Listen! (Faint sound of motor) That's them! Them lights! Come on, we got to hide out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Hide out for what? We ain't doin' nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (terrified) You're *trespassin'*! It ain't you lan' no more! An' that's the supr'tendant--with a gun!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Tom. You're on parole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: approaches at some distance, the headlights moving up and down as the car rides a dirt road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Muley leads the way.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A PART OF THE COTTON FIELD

dialogue.raw_text: All you got to do is lay down an' watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as they lie down) Won't they come out here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snickering) I don't think so. One come out here once an' I clipped him from behin' with a fence stake. They ain't bothered since.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The car stops. A strong searchlight flashes on and goes over the cabin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car moves on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in car) Muley? (After a pause) He ain't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: lie flat, listening to the sound of the car going away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He whistles, as the scene fades out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody ever 'tol me I'd be hidin' out on my own place...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: seen by daylight, fade in. The cornstalks, their roots blown clean and clear of the earth, lie fallen in one direction. This is what has happened to farms that were once rich and green. Then Uncle John's cabin comes into view. It is just after sunup. The air is filled with country sounds--a shrill chorus of birds, a dog barking in the distance. The cabin is of the same general appearance as the Joad cabin but even smaller. Smoke curls from the chimney. We see a PLATTER ON A TABLE, inside the cabin. The platter is filled with sidemeat. Over the scene comes Ma Joad's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she speaks, a man's scrawny hand reaches forward and sneaks out a piece of sidemeat. Five people are seated around the breakfast table on chairs or boxes. They are Pa, Grampa, Granma, Noah, and Uncle John. Two children, Ruthie and Winfield, stand to the table, because there are no more chairs. Their heads are all bent as Ma, standing with a fork in her hand between the table and the stove, ends the grace. Heads lift and there is a bustle as Ma turns back to the frying pork on the stove and the others truck into their food. Granma points a spiteful finger at Grampa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lord, make us thankful for what we are about to receive, for His sake. Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I seen you!--You et durin' grace!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) One little ole dab!--one teeny little ole dab!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: though they are shoveling it in, are grinning at Grampa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in a snickering whisper to Winfield) Ain't he messy though!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (viciously) I seen him!--gobblin' away like an ole pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whyn't you keep your eyes shet durin' grace, you ole...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is solemnly studying a handbill. Over his shoulder the HANDBILL can be read: "800 PICKERS WANTED--WORK IN CALIFORNIA" We see NOAH AND UNCLE JOHN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Noah frowns at the print.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (who is a half-wit) What's it say again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Says plenty work in California-- peaches. Eight hundred pickers needed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who has mush on his mouth) Wait'll I get to California! Gonna reach up and pick me an orange whenever I want it! Or grapes. That there's somethin' I ain't *never* had enough of! Gonna get me a whole bunch a grapes off a bush and I'm gonna squash 'em all over my face and just let the juice dreen down offen my chin!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a feeble bleat) Puh-raise the Lawd for vittory!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (expanding) Maybe I get me a whole *washtub* fulla them grapes and jest sit in 'em and scrooge around till they was gone! (Sighing) I shore would like to do that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: are snickering. Ruthie has smeared her face with mush. She pulls Winfield around to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She begins to slobber in mimicry. Winfield snickers. At that instant Ma enters, unobserved, and without a word give Ruthie a fine wallop. Nobody else pays any attention to the slap as Ma, a bucket in her hand, moves on toward the door. We see her now in the BACKYARD, first at the door, then moving toward the well. She stops dead still, her eyes gazing outward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Look. I'm Grampa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is looking at the household goods piled around the yard, to be taken to California. Casy is in the background. Then Tom looks up and see Ma (out of the scene). His face softens. He moves toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a sigh and a smile, and her eyes full of wonder, she feels his arm. Her fingers touch his cheek, as if she were blind. Swelling with emotion, Tom bites his lip to control himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly--her eyes closed) Thank God. Oh thank God. (In sudden terror as he approaches) Tommy, you didn't *bust* out, didya? You ain't got to hide, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Ma. I'm paroled. I got my papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was so scared we was goin' away without you--and we'd never see each other again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd a found you, Ma.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with great politeness, turns his back to the scene and keeps well away from it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: now looks around at the dusty furniture piled around the yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the DOOR, Pa is staring toward them, his mouth open.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Muley tol' me what happened, Ma. Are we goin' to California true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We *got* to, Tommy. But that's gonna be awright. I seen the han'bills, about how much work they is, an' high wages, too. But I gotta fin' out somepin' else first, Tommy. (Breathlessly) Did they hurt you, son? Did they hurt you an' make you mean-mad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) Mad, Ma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes they do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) No, Ma I was at first--but not no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not yet quite convinced) Sometimes they do somethin' to you, Tommy. They hurt you--and you get mad--and then you get mean--and they hurt you again--and you get meaner, and meaner--till you ain't no boy or no man any more, but just a walkin' chunk a mean-mad. Did they hurt you like that, Tommy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) No, Ma. You don't have to worry about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God. I--I don't want no mean son (She loves him with her eyes)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost to himself) It's Tommy! (Then shouting inside) It's Tommy back! (Heading for Tom) What'd you do, son--bust out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: all but Granma are staring toward the door. Then all but Granma scramble to their feet, headed for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children and Grampa scramble out first, followed hurriedly but less rowdily by Uncle John and Noah. Granma, aware only that there is some excitement, looks interestedly after them but decides against any activity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the BACKYARD, the prodigal son, mother and father proudly beside him, is having his hand wrung by Grampa, who vainly tries to button various buttons of his shirt, as always. The two children jump up and down excitedly but are too shy to force themselves into the reception.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Tom chucks the two children under the chin, the rattling roar of a jalopy causes all to turn to look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The roar increases. A home-built TRUCK comes around the corner of the house. Once a Hudson sedan, the top has been cut in two and a truck body constructed. It is driven now by Al, and on the front seat with him are Rosasharn and Connie. The arrival, as the truck moves into the yard, increases the excitement, and the scene is a little incoherent with the talking and shouting and the noise of the jalopy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the whoop of laughter that goes up from all, she turns in a fine simulation of maidenly mortification, and throws herself into Connie's arms, hiding her face against his chest. After a moment of surprise, a slow, happy, fatuous grin begins to broaden his face. He beams, whereupon their delight increases, the men roaring and jeering and slapping their legs, the women making modest efforts to suppress their amusement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An automobile horn sounds sharply. Their laughter halted as though cut by a knife, they look off. A TOURING CAR has stopped in the road by the house, the engine still running. One man drives, the other talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the BACKYARD the people are silent, their faces without expression, as all gaze toward the touring car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The touring car's engine is still heard after the men drive off. The Joads watch the car, their heads turning, their eyes following, expressionless. The scene dissolves to the BACKYARD just before dawn. Now and then a rooster crows. A couple of lanterns light the scene as the man load the truck. It is nearly done, the body piled high but flat with boxes, and more tied on running boards. Al has the hood open and is working on the motor. Noah, Casy, Uncle John, Connie, Pa, and Tom are at various tasks. They talk as they work.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in an excited chant) Tom's outa ja-ul! Tom's outa ja-ul!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knowed it! Couldn't keep him in! Can't keep a Joad in! I knowed it from the fust!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely) Puh-raise the Lawd for vittory! (she resumes eating)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Pa) You know what I al'ays said: "Tom'll come bustin' outa that jail like a bull through a corral fence." Can't keep no Joad in jail!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) I didn't bust out. They lemme out. Howya, Noah. Howya, Uncle John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, Tommy. Glad to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to anybody) I was the same way myself. Put me in jail and I'd bust right out. Couldn't hold me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confidentially) Bust out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Parole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Tom! Howya doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised and pleased) Rosasharn! Hi, Rosasharn! Howya, Al!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wildly) The jailbird's back! The jailbird's back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Ma! Hi, Connie! Hiya, Grampa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Tom) That's Connie Rivers with her. They're married now. (Confidentially) She's due about three-four months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (marveling) Why, she wasn't no more'n a kid when I went up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eagerly as he jumps down) You bust outa jail, Tom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patiently) Naw. They paroled me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (let down) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heh'o Tom. (Proudly) This is Connie, my husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking hands) If this don't beat all! (Chuckling) Well, I see you been busy already!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gasping) You do not see either!--not yet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lookut his face! Y'see his face? Lookut Rosasharn! Y'ever see anything like her face when Tom said it? Look around, Rosasharn! Let's see it again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Joad! John Joad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't forgot, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We ain't forgot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Comin' through here tomorrow, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. We be out. We be out by sunup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Pa) How you get all this money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sol' things, chopped cotton--even Grampa. Got us about two hunnerd dollars all tol'. Shucked out seventy- five for this truck, but we still got nearly a hunnerd and fifty to set out on. I figger we oughta be able to make it on that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Easy. After all, they ain't but about *twelve* of us, is they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly closing the hood) She'll prob'ly ride like a bull calf-- but she'll ride!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reckon we better begin roustin' 'em out if we aim to get outa here by daylight. How about it, John? How you boys comin'? (He casts a critical eye over the truck)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ma sits on a box in front of the stove. The fire door is open and the light shines out. The room itself has been pretty well stripped, with only trash and discarded things left. In Ma's lap is a pasteboard shoebox and she is going through the meager treasures stored in it, to see what must go and what she can take with her. Her eyes are soft and thoughtful as each item brings a memory, but not sad. Occasionally she smiles faintly. She pulls out a letter, looks at it, starts to throw it into the fire, then puts it back in the box. Her hand pulls out a PICTURE POSTCARD. We see it in Ma's hand. It is a picture of the Statue Of Liberty. Over it: "Greetings from New York City." She turns it over. It is addressed: "Mrs. Joad RFD 254 Oklahomy Territory." In the space for a message: "Hello honey. Willy Mae."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: after a moment of studying it, throws the card into the fire. She lifts the letter again, puts it back. She pulls out a worn NEWSPAPER CLIPPING. We see it in Ma's hand. The headline is: "JOAD GETS SEVEN YEARS."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: drops the clipping into the fire. Rummaging around, she pulls out a small CHINA DOG. We see it closely as before. On it is printed: "Souvenir of Louisiana Purchase Exposition-- St. Louis--1904."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: studies the dog, smiling, remembering something that it meant in her life. Then she puts in in a pocket in her dress. Next she pulls out some pieces of cheap jewelry; one cuff link, a baby's signet ring, two earrings. She smiles at the ring, then pockets it. The cuff link too. The earrings she holds for a moment longer, then looks around to make sure nobody sees, then holds them to her ears, not looking into any kind of a mirror, just feeling them against the lobes of her ears, as once perhaps she wore them. Her eyes are grave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom disappears. Ma looks at the earrings, and then at the contents of the box. She lifts out the letter again and looks at it. Then, without drama, she drops it into the fire. She watches it burn. Her eyes are still on the flame as she calls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The flame dies down. In the BACKYARD it is grey dawn. There is a thrill of quiet excitement as they all stand around the loaded truck, hats on, putting on coats. The ones missing are Ma, Rosasharn, the children, and Grampa. Pa is in charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom easily lifts her up the step. The two children come running out of the house, chanting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All have obeyed and are aboard but Pa, Tom, and Casy, who is watching the springs flatten out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All turn. In a CORNER OF THE HOUSE Al is pulling Grampa gently but firmly, the old man holding back, and furious. He flails feebly at Al, who holds his head out of the way without effort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al permits Grampa to jerk loose and sit down on the doorstep. The old man is miserable and frightened and angry, too old to understand or accept such a violent change in his life. Tom and Pa come up to him. The others watch solemnly from their places in the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All watch him worriedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (from the door) How about it, Ma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rosasharn honey! Wake up the chillun. We're fixin' to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Ma comes out of the cabin) Where's Grampa? Al, go git him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to climb in the front seat) I'm gonna sit up front! Somebody he'p me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goin' to California! Goin' to California!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You kids climb up first, on top. (all obey as he directs) Al's gonna drive, Ma. You sit up there with him and Granma and we'll swap around later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't gonna sit with Grampa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Connie, you he'p Rosasharn up there alongside Ruthie and Winfiel'. (Looking around) Where's Grampa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a cackle) Where he al'ays is, prob'ly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, leave him a place, but Noah, you and John, y'all kinda find yourself a place--kinda keep it even all around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think she'll hold?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If she does it'll be a miracle outa Scripture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lemmo go, gol dang it! Lemmo go, I tell you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wasn't sleepin'. He was settin' out back a the barn. They's somepin' wrong with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ef you don't let me go--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, Grampa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dully, sullenly) Ain't nothin' the matter. I just ain't a-goin', that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you mean you ain't goin'? We *got* to go. We got no place to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't talkin' about you, I'm talkin' about me. And I'm a-stayin'. I give her a good goin' over all night long-- and I'm a-stayin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you can't *do* that, Grampa. This here land is goin' under the tractor. We *all* got to git out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All but me! I'm a-stayin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How 'bout Granma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fiercely) Take her with you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting out of the truck) But who'd cook for you? How'd you live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muley's livin', ain't he? And I'm *twicet* the man Muley is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on his knee) Now listen, Grampa. Listen to me, just a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) And I ain't gonna listen either. I tol' you what I'm gonna do. (Angrily) And I don't give a hoot in a hollow if they's oranges and grapes crowdin' a fella outa bed even, I ain't a- goin' to California! (Picking up some dirt) This here's my country. I b'long *here*. (Looking at the dirt) It ain't no good-- (after a pause) --but it's mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a silence) Ma. Pa. (They move toward the cabin with him) Grampa, his eyes hurt and hunted and frightened and bewildered, scratches in the dirt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (loudly) And can't nobody *make* me go, either! Ain't nobody here *man* enough to make me! I'm a-stayin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ma is already pouring coffee into a can as GRAMPA is seen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks the coffee. Pa and Tom watch him. He notices nothing. He takes another dram of the coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks again. The scene dissolves to the TRUCK. It is just after dawn. Pa, Tom, and Noah are lifting Grampa into the truck. He mumbles angrily, but is unconscious of what is happening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The engine rattles and roars shakily. Grinning with excitement, Pa sits down and pats Grampa clumsily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truck starts to move heavily. Casy stands watching it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops politely. Pa looks from one face to the other in the truck--a swift, silent canvass--and though no one speaks or gives any other sign, Pa knows that the vote is yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly he climbs aboard. The truck rattles into motion again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they all look back the deserted CABIN is seen from the departing truck. Now we see the FAMILY IN THE TRUCK, as it snorts and rattles toward the road--a study of facial expressions as the Joad family look back for the last time at their home. Connie and Rosasharn, whispering, giggling, and slappings, are oblivious of the event. Ruthie and Winfield are trembling with excitement. But Tom's and Pa's smiles have disappeared, and all the men are gazing back thoughtfully and soberly, their minds occupied with the solemnity of this great adventure. In the FRONT SEAT OF THE TRUCK. Al is driving. Granma is already dozing. Ma looks steadily ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues to stare straight ahead. The TRUCK is lumbering up onto a paved highway. The scene dissolves to a MONTAGE: Almost filling the screen is the shield marker of the U.S. Highway 66. Superimposed on it is a montage of jalopies, steaming and rattling and piled high with goods and people, as they pull onto the highway, to indicate as much as possible that this departure of the Joad family is but part of a mass movement of jalopies and families. The signs of towns on U.S. Highway 66 flash past--
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Either we got to tie him up and *throw* him on the truck, or somepin. He can't stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't tie him. Either we'll hurt him or he'll git so mad he'll hurt his self. (After thought) Reckon we could git him *drunk*?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't no whisky, is they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait. There's a half a bottle a soothin' sirup here. (In the trash in the corner) It put the chillun to sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tasting it) Don't taste bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking in the pot) And they's some coffee here. I could fix him a cup...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. And douse some in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching) Better give him a good 'un. He's awful bull-headed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mumbling defiantly) If Muley can scrabble along, I can do it too. (Suddenly sniffing) I smell spareribs. Somebody been eatin' spareribs? How come I ain't got some?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (from the door) Got some saved for you, Grampa. Got 'em warmin' now. Here's a cuppa coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking the cup) Awright, but get me some a them spareribs, too. Get me a whole mess of 'em. I'm hongry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amiably) I shore do like spareribs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fretfully) Easy, *easy!* You wanta bust his head wide open? Pull his arms, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mumbling) Ain't a-goin', thas all...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put somepin' over him, so he won't git sun-struck. (Looking around) Ever'body set now? (A chorus of responses) Awright, Al, letta go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You be awright, Grampa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good-by, an' good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, wait! Hold 'er, Al! (The car stops) Ain't you goin' with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) I'd like to. There's somethin' happenin' out there in the wes' an' I'd like to try to learn what it is. If you feel you got the room...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (heartily) Come on, get on, plenty room!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, come on, Casy, plenty room!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) Here we go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) California, here we come!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Ain't you gonna look back, Ma?--give the ol' place a last look?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly shaking her head) We're goin' to California, ain't we? Awright then, let's *go* to California.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobering) That don't sound like you, Ma. You never was like that before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never had my house pushed over before. I never had my fambly stuck out on the road. I never had to lose... ever'thing I had in life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . This dissolves to a HIGHWAY. It is late afternoon. The Joad truck pulls of the paved highway and stops. The men leap down quickly from the truck, all but Pa, who lifts Grampa in his arms and then lowers him slowly, gently into Tom's arms. In TOM'S arms Grampa is whimpering feebly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a quilt pulled from the truck Ma runs ahead as Tom carries Grampa toward a clump of woods back off the highway. The others get down soberly from the truck, all but Granma, who is dozing. Cars pass-a fast car passing a jalopy. Tom is letting the old man down gently as Ma adjusts the quilt on the ground. Death is in Grampa's eyes as he looks up dimly at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to an insert of a NOTE. It is written awkwardly in pencil on the flyleaf of a Bible. Tom's voice recites the words.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: *Ain't* a-goin'... ain't a-goin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: all right, Grampa. You just kind a tar'd, that's all. Somebody fix a pallet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Thas it, jus' tar'd thas all... jus' tar'd... (He closes his eyes)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This here is William James Joad, dyed of a stroke, old old man. His folkes bured him becaws they got no money to pay for funerls. Nobody kilt him. Jus a stroke an he dyed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at night. In the clump of woods, lighted by two lanterns, The Joad tribe stands reverently around an open grave. Having read the note, Tom puts it in a small fruit jar and kneels down and, reaching into the grave, places it on Grampa's body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene fades out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I figger best we leave something like this on him, lest somebody dig him up and make out he been kilt. (Reaching into the grave) Lotta times looks like the gov'ment got more interest in a dead man than a live one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not be so lonesome, either, knowin' his name is there with 'im, not just' a old fella lonesome underground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (straightening up) Casy, won't you say a few words?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't no more a preacher, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We know. But ain't none of our folks ever been buried without a few words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) I'll say 'em--an' make it short. (All bow and close eyes) This here ol' man jus' lived a life an' jus' died out of it. I don't know whether he was good or bad, an' it don't matter much. Heard a fella say a poem once, an' he says, "All that lives is holy." But I wouldn't pray for jus' a ol' man that's dead, because he's awright. If I was to pray I'd pray for the folks that's alive an' don't know which way to turn. Grampa here, he ain't got no more trouble like that. He's got his job all cut out for 'im--so cover 'im up and let 'im get to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in daylight, fades in: an Oklahoma stretch, revealing a number of jalopies rattling westward. The Joad truck approaches. In the FRONT SEAT OF THE TRUCK Tom is now driving. Granma is dozing again, and Ma is looking thoughtfully ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the truck slows to a stop a motorcycle cop approaches after them. Looking back, Tom sees him bearing toward them. He looks grimly at Ma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cop looks startled, puzzled, but Tom shrugs a disclaimer for responsibility in that quarter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Ma helps Granma out the other side, Tom and the cop exchange a glance and snother shrug at the foibles of women and then look studiedly into space. The scene dissolves to a MONTAGE: superimposed on the marker of U.S. Highway 66 an assortment of roadside signs flashes by: Bar-B-Q, Joe's Eats, Dr. Pepper, Gas, Coca Cola, This Highway is Patrolled, End of 25 Mile Zone, Lucky Strikes, Used Cars, Nutburger, Motel, Drive-Inn, Free Water, We Fix Flats, etc.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Ma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wasn't that the state line we just passed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Yes'm, that was it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your pa tol' me you didn't ought to cross it if you're paroled. Says they'll send you up again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it, Ma. I got her figgered out. Long as I keep outa trouble, ain't nobody gonna say a thing. All I gotta do is keep my nose clean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worriedly) Maybe they got crimes in California we don't know about. Crimes we don't even know *is* crimes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Forget it, Ma. Jus' think about the nice things out there. Think about them grapes and oranges--an' ever'body got work--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waking suddenly) I gotta git out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First gas station, Granma--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta git *out*, I tell ya! I gotta git *out*!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (foot on brakes) Awright! Awright!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They shore don't waste no time! (As Granma whines) Take her out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (astraddle his motorcycle) Save your strength, lady. (to Tom) Get goin', buddy. No campin' here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (relieved) We ain't campin'. We jus' stoppin' a minute--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lissen, I heard that before--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tell ya I gotta git out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly) She's kinda ol'--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whimpering) I tell ya--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, okay!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (triumphantly) Puh-raise the Lawd for vittory!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: reads: "CAMP 50." It is night. We hear the sound of guitar music. In the CAMP GROUND a small wooden house dominates the scene. There are no facilities; the migrants simply pitch makeshift tents and park their jalopies wherever there is a space. It is after supper and a dozen or more men sit on the steps of the house listening to Connie play a road song on a borrowed guitar. The music softens the tired, drawn faces of the men and drives away some of their shyness. In the dark, outside the circle of light from the gasoline lantern on the porch, some of the women and children sit and enjoy the luxury of this relative gaiety. The proprietor sits tipped back in a straight chair on the porch. We see the JOAD TENT. Behind their truck, a tarpaulin is stretched over a rope from tree to tree. Granma lies asleep on a quilt, stirring fitfully. Ma sits on the ground at her head, fanning her with a piece of cardboard. Rosasharn lies flat on her back, hands clasped under her head, looking up at the stars. The music comes to them pleasantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the music ends we see a GROUP ON THE PORCH STEPS. The men murmur approbation of Connie's playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they talk, a SECOND MAN, standing on the edge of the group, begins to grin bitterly. He is much more ragged than the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The GROUP turns to look at the Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Man begins to snigger and then to laugh in a high whinneying giggle which turns into a fit of coughing. All of the men are watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least three-quarters of the men worriedly reach into their pockets and draw out worn and folded handbills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long worried silence. The proprietor leans forward angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks around at the men, trying to control his emotions, and then he walks away into the darkness. There is an uneasy silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all rise as at a signal, all moved and worried by the Second Man's outburst. TOM, PA AND CASY move away, worry on their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to a MONTAGE: superimposed on the shield marker of U.S. Highway 66 and the rattling Joad truck the signs of towns flash by: AMARILLO, VEGA, GLENRIO. The TRUCK is seen on the HIGHWAY. It is now mountain country-- New Mexico. Then it is seen at a GAS STATION. It is a cheap two-pump station, hand-painted, dreary, dusty. Huddled next to it is a hamburger stand. In front of the hamburger stand is a truck labeled: NEW MEXICO VAN AND STORAGE COMPANY. The Joads are piling out of their truck. Directed by Ma, Noah lifts Granma out. The two children scamper around shrieking because their legs have gone to sleep. Al is preparing to put water in the radiator. Pa takes out a deep leather pouch, unties the strings, and begins calculating his money as the fat proprietor advances.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ma... all this, will it hurt the baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now don't you go gettin' nimsy-mimsy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes I'm all jumpy inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, can't nobody get through nine *months* without sorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But will it--hurt the baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They use' to be a sayin': A chile born outa sorrow'll be a happy chile. An' another: Born outa too much joy'll be a doleful boy. That's the way I always heard it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't ever get scairt, do you, Ma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thoughtfully) Sometimes. A little. Only it ain't scairt so much. It's just waitin' an' wonderin'. But when sump'n happens that I got to do sump'n-- (simply) --I'll do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't it ever scare you it won't be nice in California like we think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) No. No, it don't. I can't do that. I can't let m'self. All I can do is see how soon they gonna wanta eat again. They'd all get upset if I done anymore 'n that. They all depen' on me jus' thinkin' about that. (After a pause) That's my part--that an' keepin' the fambly together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with quiet pride) Thas my son-in-law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sings real nice. What state y'all from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oklahoma. Had us a farm there, share- croppin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Till the tractors druv us out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We from Arkansas. I had me a store there, kind of general notions store, but when the farms went the store went too. (Sighing) Nice a little as you ever saw. I shore did hate to give it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (profoundly) Wal, y'cain't tell. I figure when we git out there an' git work an' maybe git us a piece a growin' lan' near water it might not be so bad at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thas right... Payin' good wages, I hear... Ever'body got work out there... Can't be no worse...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You folks must have a pot a money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with dignity) No, we ain't got no money. But they's plenty of us to work, an' we 're all good men. Get good wages out there an' put it all together an' we'll be awright.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good wages, eh! Pickin' oranges an' peaches?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) We gonna take whatever they got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so funny about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sniggering again) What's so funny about it?  I just *been* out there! I been an' *seen* it! An' I'm goin' *back* to starve-- because I ruther starve all over at once!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Whatta you think you're talkin' about? I got a han'bill here says good wages, an' I seen it in the papers they need pickers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Awright, go on! Ain't nobody stoppin' ya!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling out handbill) But what about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't gonna fret you. Go on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute, buddy. You jus' done some jackassin'! You ain't gonna shut up now. The han'bill says they need men. You laugh an' say they don't. Now which one's a liar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) How many you'all got them han'bills? Come on, how many?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what does *that* prove?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at 'em! Same yella han'bill--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: pickers wanted. Awright, this man wants 800 men. So he prints up 5,000 a them han'bills an' maybe 20,000 people sees 'em. An' maybe two-three thousan' starts movin, wes' account a this han'bill. Two- three thousan' folks that's crazy with worry headin' out for 800 jobs! Does that make sense?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you, a troublemaker? You sure you ain't one a them labor fakes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swear I ain't, mister!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, don't you go roun' here tryin' to stir up trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drawing himself up) I tried to tell you folks sump'n it took me a year to fin' out. Took two kids dead, took my wife dead, to show me. But nobody couldn't tell me neither. I can't tell ya about them little fellas layin' in the tent with their bellies puffed out an' jus' skin on their bones, an' shiverin' an' whinin' like pups, an' me runnin' aroun' tryin' to get work-- (shouting) --not for money, not for wages--jus' for a cup a flour an' a spoon a lard! An' then the coroner came. "Them children died a heart-failure," he says, an' put it in his paper. (With wild bitterness) Heart-failure!--an' their little bellies stuck out like a pig-bladder!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well--gettin' late. Got to get to sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: S'pose he's tellin' the truth--that fella?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's tellin' the truth awright. The truth for him. He wasn't makin' nothin' up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about us? Is that the truth for us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: NEW MEXICO VAN AND STORAGE COMPANY

dialogue.raw_text: (worriedly) How can you tell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (truculently) You folks aim to buy anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Need some gas, mister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got any money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatta you think:--we's beggin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just ast, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (evenly) Well, ask right. You ain't talkin' to bums, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (appealing to heaven) All in the worl' I done was ast!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a standard cheap eatery, Bert is doing the short orders and Mae is handling the counter. A nickel phonograph is playing a tune. Bill, a truck driver, sits at the counter; his partner, Fred, is playing a slot machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops. Pa is peering in the screen door. Beside him Ruthie and Winfield have their noses flattened against the screen. Mae looks at Pa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae shrugs at the truck drivers, to indicate what she's up against, while Bert mashes his hamburgers savagely with the spatula.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pa and the two children come in as Mae opens a drawer and pulls out a long waxpaper-covered loaf of bread. The children have been drawn to the candy showcase and are staring in at the goodies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taking out his pouch, Pa digs into it, feels around with his fingers for a dime, as he apologizes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But when he puts the dime down on the counter he has a penny with it. He is about to drop this back in the pouch when his eyes fall on the children staring at the candy. Slowly he moves down to see what they are looking at. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children look up with a gasp, their big eyes on Mae as she moves down behind the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae looks from the candy to the children. They have stopped breathing, their eyes on the candy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He places the penny carefully on the counter and Mae holds the sticks of candy out to the children. They look up at Pa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rigid with embarrassment, they accept the candy, looking neither at it nor at each other. Pa picks up the loaf of bread and they scramble for the door. At the door Pa turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door slams. Bill turns back from staring after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both reach in their pockets, but when Fred sees what Bill has put down he reaches again and duplicates it. As they go out of the door...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Mae watches them through the window, her eyes warm, Bert walks around the counter to the three slot machines, a paper with figures on it in his hand. The truck roars outside and moves off. Mae looks down again at the coins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he looks we see the COINS ON THE COUNTER. They are two half-dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a rattle of coins as Bert hits the jackpot. In his left hand on the machine is a paper with three columns of figures on it. The third column is much the longest. He scoops out the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene fades out. The ARIZONA BORDER, in daylight, fades in. It is in a gap in the mountains and beyond can be seen the Painted Desert. A border guard halts the Joad truck. He is not as tough as his words indicate, just curt and matter-of-fact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truck rattles into movement. The scene dissolves to a MONTAGE superimposed on the shield marker of U.S. Highway 66 and the Joad truck. Signs flash by: FLAGSTAFF, WATER 5 A GAL, WATER 10 A GAL, WATER 15 A GAL, and finally, NEEDLES, CALIF. In the foreground, their backs turned, the Joads stand on and about their truck looking in a long silence at what can be seen of California from Needles. Their silence is eloquent. The faces of the Joads are blank with dismay, for this is an unattractive sight indeed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other in disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Joads and the landscape are seen again. Then the scene dissolves to the BANK OF A RIVER. The camp at Needles is on the bank of the Colorado River, among some willows. We see the man of the family sitting chest-deep in the shallow waters, talking, occasionally ducking their heads under, reveling in this relief. In the background are the towering mountains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look up as a man and his grown son stand on the bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to shuck off their clothes. THE MAN, excluding those undressing, form another scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man and his son sit down in the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long silence among the Joads as the man and his son splash water over their heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man and his son exchange a glance, as though the Joads had touched on the deadliest of subjects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a disturbed silence as the Joads study the man, but he obviously has no intention of saying anything more. Finally Pa turns to his brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to a GAS STATION, at night. The Joad truck, loaded with goods and people, is last gas and servicing before the desert. Two white uniformed boys handle the station. A sign reads: "LAST CHANCE FOR GAS AND WATER." Al is filling the radiator. Tom is counting out the money for the gas.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kinda pie y'got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Banana cream, pineapple cream, chocolate cream--and apple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cut me off a hunk a that banana cream, and a cuppa java.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make it two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two it is. (Smirking) Seen any new etchin's lately, Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Well, here's one ain't bad. Little kid comes in late to school. Teacher says--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could you see your way clear to sell us a loaf of bread, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This ain't a groc'ry store. We got bread to make san'widges with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, ma'am... on'y it's for a ole lady, no teeth, gotta sof'n it with water so she can chew it, an' she's hongry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whyn't you buy a san'wich? We got nice san'widges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrassed) I shore would like to do that, ma'am, but the fack is, we ain't got but a dime for it. It's all figgered out, I mean--for the trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't get no loaf a bread for a dime. We only got fifteen-cent loafs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an angry whisper) Give 'em the bread.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll run out 'fore the bread truck comes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Awright then, run out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This here's a fifteen-cent loaf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you--could you see your way to cuttin' off ten cents worth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a clinched teeth order) Give 'im the loaf!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir, we wanta buy ten cents worth, thas all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighing) You can have this for ten cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't wanta rob you, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with resignation) Go ahead--Bert says take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May soun' funny to be so tight, but we got a thousan' miles to go, an' we don't know if we'll make it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is them penny candy, ma'am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which ones?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There, them stripy ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, them? Well, no--them's *two* for a penny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, give me two then, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beaming) Sure, take 'em, take 'em!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Them wasn't two-for-a-cent candy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (belligerently) What's it to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Them was nickel apiece candy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got to get goin'. We're droppin' time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, wait a minute. You got change comin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (from outside) What's it to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Bert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playing a machine) What ya want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reverently) Truck drivers.
dialogue.name: dialogue
