dialogue.raw_text: I figgered No. 3 was about ready to pay off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who is driving) California.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long you plan to be in Arizona?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No longer'n we can get acrost her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got any plants?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No plants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rallying them) Aw, sure. This here's jus' a part of it. Ain't no sense a gettin' scairt right off.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got that desert yet. Gotta take her tonight. Take her in the daytime fella says she'll cut your gizzard out.

dialogue.raw_text: (to Al) How's Granma since we got her in the tent?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's off her chump, seems to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's outa her senses, awright. All night on the truck keep talkin' like she was talkin' to Grampa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's jus' wore out, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worriedly) I shore would like to stop here a while an' give her some res' but we on'y got 'bout forty dollars left. I won't feel right till we're there an' all workin' an' a little money comin' in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lazily, after a silence) Like to jus' stay here myself. Like to lay here forever. Never get hungry an' never get sad. Lay in the water all life long, lazy as a brood sow in the mud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up at the mountains) Never seen such tough mountains. This here's a murder country, just the *bones* of a country. (Thoughtfully) Wonder if we'll ever get in a place where folks can live 'thout fightin' hard scrabble an' rock. Sometimes you get to thinkin' they *ain't* no such country.

dialogue.raw_text: How's the swimmin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dunno. We ain't tried none. Sure feels good to set here, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind if we come in an' set?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She ain't our river. But we'll len' you a little piece of her.

dialogue.raw_text: Goin' west?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. We come from there. Goin' back home.

dialogue.raw_text: Where's home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Panhandle, come from near Pampa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in surprise) Can you make a livin' there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) But at leas' we can starve to death with folks we know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) Ya know, you're the second fella talked like that. I'd like to hear some more about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me an' you both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) He ain't gonna tell you nothin' about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If a fella's willin' to work hard, can't he cut her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, mister. I don't know ever'thing. You might go out an' fall into a steady job, an' I'd be a liar. An' then, you might never get no work, an' I didn't warn you. All I can tell ya, most of the folks is purty mis'able. (Sullenly) But a fella don't know ever'thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, you never was a fella to say much, but I'll be goldanged if you opened your mouth twicet since we lef' home. What you think about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scowling) I don't think *nothin'* about it. We're a-goin' there, ain't we?  When we get there, we'll get there. When we get a job, we'll work, an' when we don't get a job we'll set on our behin's. That's all they is to it, ain't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Uncle John don't talk much but when he does he shore talks sense. (He spurts water out of his mouth)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You people got a lotta nerve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Crossin' the desert in a jalopy like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You been acrost?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, plenty, but not in no wreck like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we broke down maybe somebody'd give us a han'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (doubtfully) Well, maybe. But I'd hate to be doin' it. Takes more nerve than I got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) It don't take no nerve to do somep'n when there ain't nothin' else you can do. (He climbs into the driver's seat)

Taking it from the book, there is a breath-taking view of the valley from where Highway 66 comes out of the mountains. This is the California the Joads have dreamed of, rich and beautiful, the land of milk and honey. It is just daybreak, with the sun at the Joad's back. They have pulled off the side of the road and stopped, just to drink in the sight. They are looking almost reverently at the sight before them as they climb stiffly out of the truck.

direction.raw_text: by day, fades in. Down a town or small city business street, with quite a bit of traffic, comes the Joad truck being pushed by the Joad men. At the wheel, aiming at a corner gas station, is Rosasharn, frightened and uncertain, with Ma beside her on the front seat. In the back Ruthie and Winfield are delighted with this new form of locomotion. Crossing the street, a policeman falls into step with Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a two-pump station and one of the pumps has a car, with the attendant servicing it. The Joad truck stops by the other pump and Tom, wiping his face with his sleeve, grins and address himself to the policeman. The others stand listening solemnly in the background.

direction.raw_text: He strolls away, the Joads looking concernedly after him, just as the gas station attendant comes briskly to them after disposing of the other car.

direction.raw_text: The attendant regards him in disgust. The scene dissolves to HOOVERVILLE, by day. A large migrant camp, a typical shanty town of ragged tents and tarpaper shacks, jalopies and dirty children. A dozen or more children pause to watch as the Joad truck lumbers down a dirt incline from the road and stops at the edge of the camp in front of one of the most miserable of the shacks. The Joads regard the camp with dismay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truck moves into the camp through a lane of children. The scene dissolves to the JOAD TENT. In front of it, Ma is on her knees feeding a small fire with broken sticks. On the fire is a pot of stew. Ruthie and Winfield stand watching the pot. About fifteen ragged, barefooted children in a half- circle are now around the fire, their solemn eyes on the pot of stew. Occasionally they look at Ma, then back at the stew. Presently one of the older girls speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long silence. Then:

He is raising the first spoonful to his mouth when he notices them apparently for the first time. He is chewing slowly, his eyes on the children, their eyes on his face, when Tom and Al enter.

direction.raw_text: The children retreat a step, but no more, and then look wonderingly at him.

direction.raw_text: She goes in the tent hurriedly to hide the fact that tears have come into her eyes. The children pounce on the pot, silently, too busy digging for the stew to speak.

direction.raw_text: are squatting in a half-circle, the usual pattern for conversation, but they are silent now as their eyes fix on the man approaching. He is a labor agent.

direction.raw_text: the men are looking in the direction of the group. They start to walk toward it.

direction.raw_text: : The agent, wearing a flat-brimmed Stetson and with his pockets filled with pencils and dog-eared booklets, looks down at the silent men. All of the men in the camp are approaching slowly, silently. The women give their anxious attention in the background. Among the men who walk up is FLOYD, a grimly disappointed young man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The squatting men have risen one by one. Their faces are expressionless because they simply don't know when one of these calls is genuine or when it isn't. Floyd addresses them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other man gets out of the COUPE. He wears riding breeches and laced boots, carries a pistol and cartridge belt, and there is a deputy sheriff's star on his brown shirt. He smiles thinly and shifts his pistol holster as he starts toward the group. THE MEN are watching the deputy approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men say nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the agent gets into the coupe FLOYD'S thumbs hook over his belt and he looks off, away. TOM'S look away is an answer. His thumbs also hook over his belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes hold of Floyd's left arm. At the same time Floyd swings, smacks him in the face. As the deputy staggers, Tom sticks out a foot and trips him. Floyd is already running through the camp. The deputy fires from the ground. There is a scream. A WOMAN is looking down at her hand, the knuckles shot away. The COUPE is seen as the agent steps on the gas to get away. As Floyd gets in the clear, the DEPUTY, sitting on the ground, aims his pistol again, slowly, carefully. Behind him Casy steps up, gauges his distance, and then kicks him square in the base of the skull. The deputy tumbles over unconscious. Tom picks up the pistol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Tom strides away there is the distant sound of a siren. Casy empties the gun and throws cartridges and gun aside. The men, aghast, have been standing back, worried and excited and apprehensive. They wish nothing like this had happened. The women have gathered around the wounded woman, who is sobbing. Now at the sound of the siren everybody begins to move uncomfortably toward his tent or shack. Al looks admiringly from Casy to the unconscious deputy. Everybody has disappeared into his tent but Al and Casy. The siren draws nearer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al heads for the Joad tent and Casy kneels down and lifts the deputy. He wipes his face clean. The deputy begins to come to. An open car curves off the highway, stops in the clearing, and four men with rifles pile out. The deputy sits rubbing his eyes and Casy stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two of the men have helped the deputy to his feet. He feels the back of his neck gingerly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a deputy on either side of him, Casy climbs in the back seat. The sickish deputy is helped into the car. The other man comes running back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car starts. CASY and two deputies beside him are revealed in the back seat. Casy sits proudly, head up, eyes front. On his lips is a faint smile; on his face, a curious look of conquest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Casy sits with eyes front. AT THE WILLOWS, screened by trees or brush, Tom looks off at the car taking Casy away. Starting at a sound, he withdraws into the brush as the scene dissolves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene dissolves to the ENTRANCE OF THE HOOPER RANCH in daylight. A gravel road leads from the paved highway to the big wire gates, which are enclosed. Along the side of the paved highway are parked a dozen jalopies, the migrants sitting soberly in them. Fifty or sixty other migrants line the gravel road and the junction with the paved highway. Five jalopies are in line waiting to enter the gates. And the scene is overwhelmingly policed. There must be ten motorcycle cops around. Six are dismounted and strolling to keep order among the migrants along the road. Three, their motorcycles roaring, flank the line of five jalopies. As the Joad truck drives up, we see the FRONT SEAT. Tom, Al, and Ma are beholding the scene with bewilderment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The motorcycle escort forms around the line of six cars and a deafening din is raised, of motorcycles, sirens, and an inexplicable blowing of horns on the jalopies. At the same time, as the gates open and the six cars start through, flanked by the motorcycle cops, the migrants begin spasmodic shouts, but what they say cannot be understood. As the cars move slowly, Tom and Al in the FRONT SEAT are puzzled and worried at the demonstration.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back?--or you want me to whistle up some help and take you back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll walk back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: across the road from the wire fence: Tom clambers down it, moving quietly. He picks his way down the shallow ravine.

direction.raw_text: : there is a light inside and there are the shadows of figures. In the background, beyond the tent, is the silhouette of a small concrete bridge spanning a small stream. Following a trail, Tom enters and approaches the tent. (The opening is away from him.) IN FRONT OF THE TENT, a man sitting on a box looks up suspiciously as Tom enters. His name is Joe.

direction.raw_text: A head sticks out of the tent. Until he speaks, Tom does not recognize Casy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Evenin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jus' goin' pas', that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know anybody here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Jus' goin' pas', I tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Casy! What you doin' here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if it ain't Tom Joad. How ya, boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thought you was in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I done my time an' got out. Come on in. (He pulls Tom into the tent.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: three other men sit on the ground as Casy brings Tom in. One's name is Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They listen. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank's head sticks in the door. His voice is an excited whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly Casy turns the light down and out. He gropes for the door, followed by Tom and the other man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This the fella you been talkin' about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is him. What you doin' here, Tommy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Workin'. Pickin' peaches. But I seen a bunch a fellas yellin' when we come in, so I come out to see what's goin' on. What's it all about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This here's a strike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) Well, fi' cents a box ain't much, but a fella can eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fi' cents! They pain' you fi' cents?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. We made a buck since midday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a long silence) Lookie, Tom. We come to work here. They tell us it's gonna be fi' cents. But they was a whole lot of us, so the man says two an' a half cents. Well, a fella can't even eat on that, an' if he got kids... (After a pause) So we says we won't take it. So they druv us off. Now they're payin' you five--but when they bust this strike ya think they'll pay five?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dunno. Payin' five now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soberly) I don't expeck we can las' much longer-- some a the folks ain't et for two days. You goin' back tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I aim to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (earnestly) Well--tell the folks inside how it is, Tom. Tell 'em they're starvin' us and stabbin' theirself in the back. An' as sure as God made little apples it's goin' back to two an' a half jus' as soon as they clear us out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly) You hear sump'n?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell 'em. But I don't know how. Never seen so many guys with guns. Wouldn't even let us talk today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try an' tell 'em, Tom. They'll get two an' a half, jus' the minute we're gone. An' you know what that is? That's one ton a peaches picked an' carried for a dollar. That way you can't even buy food enough to keep you alive! Tell 'em to come out with us, Tom! Them peaches is *ripe*. Two days out an' they'll pay *all* of us five!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They won't. They're a-gettin' five an' they don't care about nothin' else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But jus' the minute they ain't strike- breakin' they won't get no five!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) An' the nex' thing you know you'll be out, because they got it all figgered down to a T--until the harvest is in you're a *migrant* worker--afterwards, just a bum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five they're a-gettin' now, an' that's all they're int'rested in. I know exackly what Pa'd say. He'd jus' say it wasn't none a his business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) I guess that's right. Have to take a beatin' before he'll know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We was outa food. Tonight we had meat. Not much, but we had it. Think Pa's gonna give up his meat on account a other fellas? An' Rosasharn needs milk. Think Ma's gonna starve that baby jus' cause a bunch a fellas is yellin' outside a gate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sadly) Got to learn, like I'm a-learnin'. Don't know it right yet myself, but I'm tryin' to fin' out. That's why I can't ever be a preacher again. Preacher got to *know*. (Shaking his head) I don't. I got to *ask*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sticking his head in tent) I don't like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't tell. Seems like I hear sump'n, an' then I listen an' they ain't nothin' to hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) 'Tain't outa the question, y'know. (He exits)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of us a little itchy. Cops been tellin' us how they gonna beat us up an' run us outa the country. Not them reg'lar deppities, but them tin- star fellas they got for guards. (After a pause) They figger I'm the leader because I talk so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn out that light an' come outside. They's sump'n here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There are night sounds but little else to be distinguished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Casy leads the way softly. THE BRIDGE SPAN is seen from the stream as Casy, Tom, and the other man wade carefully toward it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dunno. Listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't tell if you hear it or not. You hear it, Tom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) I hear it. I think they's some guys comin' this way, lots of 'em. We better get outa here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Down that way--under the bridge span.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: it is almost black as they creep through the culvert. Just as Casy and Tom step out from under the bridge on the other side, a blinding flashlight hits them, lighting them like day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halted, uncertain, they stand as three men with stars on their coats and pickhandles in their hands slide down the EMBANKMENT. Two of them hold lighted flashlights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are faint responses from a distance. CASY AND TOM are alone. The others have fled. The deputies approach, their lights on Casy and Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He swings the pickhandle. Casy dodges but the stick cracks his skull. He falls face down out of the light. The deputies watch for a moment but Casy doesn't stir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bending over, their bodies hide Casy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There they are! Stand where you are!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's him! That one in the middle, the skinny one! Chuck! Alec! Here they are! We got 'em!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, you fellas. You don't know what you're doin'. You're helpin' to stave kids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up, you red--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like to me you killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn him over. Put the light on him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: seen close, is breathing hard, his eyes glistening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the deputies straighten up, Tom steps forward, grabs the pickhandle from the man who felled Casy, and swings. The blow strikes the deputy's arm, sending his flashlight flying, and the scene is in semi-darkness as Tom swings again. There is a grunt and a groan as the deputy goes down. Then all is confusion. Backing away, swinging the pickhandle, Tom bolts, splashes a few yards through the stream, turns and gains a better start by throwing the pickhandle at his pursuers. They duck, and Tom disappears into the night. The other men rush through the scene in pursuit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Serves him right, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is seen bending over the body of the man Tom laid out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The light flashes on the man's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's that flash?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (awed) Boy, he's *good* and dead! You see that fella that done it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't sure--but I caught him one across the face, and believe me, I give him a trade-mark *he* ain't gonna be able to shake off easy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is seen crashing through the bushes, his face bloody. The scene fades out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fades in. It is day. Ma comes down the street with a bundle under her arm and enters the house.

direction.raw_text: Rosasharn sits by the window as Ma enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rosasharn takes her post at the door as Ma kneels on the floor beside Tom, puts down the rag bundle, and gets a basin. Tom, who is under a quilt, is with his back alone visible. She speaks softly, guardedly, as she bathes his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom puts his head under the quilt. Ma turns, faces the door, her body protectively between Tom and whatever threatens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody ask anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No'm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand by the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's it feel, Tommy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Busted my cheek but I can still see. What'd you hear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like you done it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soberly) I kinda thought so. Felt like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Folks ain't talkin' about much else. They say they got posses out. Talkin' about a lynchin'--when they catch the fella.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They killed Casy first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That ain't the way they're tellin' it. They're sayin' you done it fust.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) They know what--this fella looks like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They know he got hit in the face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) I'm sorry, Ma. But--I didn't know what I was doin', no more'n when you take a breath. I didn't even know I was gonna do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's awright, Tommy. I wisht you didn't do it, but you done what you had to do. I can't read no fault in you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna go away tonight. I can't go puttin' this on you folks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Tom! They's a whole lot I don't understan', but goin' away ain't gonna ease us. (Thoughtfully) They was the time when we was on the lan'. They was a bound'ry to us then. Ol' folks died off, an' little fellas come, an' we was always one thing-- we was the fambly--kinda whole an' clear. But now we ain't clear no more. They ain't nothin' keeps us clear. Al--he's a-hankerin' an' a- jibbitin' to go off on his own. An' Uncle John is just a-draggin' along. Pa's lost his place--he ain't the head no more. We're crackin' up, Tom. They ain't no fambly now. Rosasharn-- (a glance at the girl) --she gonna have her baby, but *it* ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tiredly) Okay, Ma. I shouldn't, though. I know I shouldn't. But okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here come a lot of people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten of us. Whatcha payin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the bookkeeper has encountered the newcomers.

direction.raw_text: At night, the TRUCK is backed up to the door of House 63; it is already loaded. Ma is speaking in a low voice to Tom, who is peering out from under a mattress in the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom disappears. Ma turns, her back to the truck. The guard plays his flashlight on the Joads, who stand watching him ominously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly, Al is in the driver's seat, with Ma and Pa beside him. The truck rattles into motion and moves down the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: House 25. Number's on the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, mister. Whatcha payin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two and a half cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Two an' a half! Say, mister, a man can't make his dinner on that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it or leave it. There's 200 men coming from the South that'll be glad to get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But--but how we gonna eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I didn't set the price. I'm just working here. If you want it, take it. If you don't, turn right around and beat it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sullenly) Which way is House 25?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) That Casy. He might a been a preacher, but--he seen a lot a things clear. He was like a lantern--he helped mw see things too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Comes night we'll get outa here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's jus' till we get some distance. Then you can come out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd hate to get *trapped* in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's goin' on here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're goin' out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got a job offered--good job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Let's have a look at you. (He plays his flashlight on the truck) Wasn't there another fella with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess that's what he looked like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking hard) What'd he look like again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Short fella. Pale face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was he bruised up this mornin'? About the face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't see nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) Okay. Go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: another guard flashes a light as Al stops the car.

direction.raw_text: He opens the gate and the truck goes through. It turns from the gravel road onto the paved highway.

dialogue.raw_text: Goin' out for good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Goin' north. Got a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Al shows his pleased pride in her quiet approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TRUCK is rattling along the highway. Next, it is day, and the TRUCK is still churning along. In the FRONT SEAT, Tom is driving, his cap pulled as far down as possible over his wounded cheek. Rosasharn has taken Pa's place and is leaning wearily against Ma's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TRUCK keeps moving along. Then it is night, and the TRUCK is still making distance. On a COUNTRY ROAD, in grey dawn, with a deafening clank under the hood, the Joad truck pulls to a stop off the side of the road. Al is driving. Asleep in Tom's arm in the front seat, Ma stirs awake as Al turns off the ignition and gets out. He lifts the hood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls out the pieces. Tom gets out and takes off the radiator cap. There is a geyser of steam. In the back of the truck the others stand looking on, sleepy-eyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look around. At first they find nothing in sight. Al and Tom look at each other in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All look. Tom climbs on the running board the better to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Al starts the truck, the scene dissolves to a weather- beaten wooden sign: "PERMANENT CAMP NO. 9"  "DEPT. OF AGRICULTURE" We see the GATE TO THE GOVERNMENT CAMP, a wide gate in a high wire fence, with a caretaker's shack to one side of the gate. The caretaker stands beside his shack as the Joad truck swings off the road, hits an unnoticed rut that bounces the whole truck off the ground, and stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the FRONT SEAT Al leans angrily out of the driver's window. Tom is keeping his face away from the caretaker's line of vision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al starts climbing out. Pa jumps down from the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Ma, Pa, and Al look at each other in almost incredulous bewilderment, Tom climbs out of the truck.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: IN THE FRONT SEAT OF THE TRUCK

dialogue.raw_text: You done good, Al. Just good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know where we're a-goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking her head) Don't matter. Just got to go--an' keep a-goin', till we get plenty a distance away from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ma... you know, if Connie was here I wouldn't min' any a this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, honey, an' just as soon as we get settled Al's gonna set out an' look for him. How 'bout gas, Tommy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Full up. Uncle John come through with five bucks he been hol'in' out on us since we lef' home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's hotter'n a heifer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fan-belt's shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around) Picks a nice place for it, too, don't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any gas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gallon or two?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whistling) Well, looks like we done it this time awright!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing in truck) Tommy. (Pointing) Some smoke up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like about a mile. Reckon she'll make it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She got to make it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as they get back in) What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't know--but it's better'n this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly) You hit 'er too fast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the idea of that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chuckling) Well, a lot a kids play in here. You tell folks to go slow and they liable to forget. But let 'em hit that hump once and they don't forget!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got any room here for us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) You're lucky. Fellow just moved out half-hour ago. (Pointing) Down that line and turn to the left. You'll see it. You'll be in No. 4 Sanitary Unit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Toilet and showers and washtubs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you got *washtubs?* An' runnin' water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. (To Al) Camp committee'll call on you in the morning and get you fixed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Cops?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No cops. Folks here elect their own cops. (To Ma) The ladies' committee'll call on you, ma'am, about the kids and the sanitary unit and who takes care of 'em. (To Al) Come inside and sign up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take 'er on down, Al. I'll sign.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We gonna stay, ain't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're tootin' we're gonna stay. (He follows the caretaker into the shack)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tom enters warily, alert for any indication that either his name or his scar may have been learned and telegraphed here. But the caretaker obviously attaches no significance to either. The shack is bare but for a cot, a table, a chair, and an electric light. The caretaker is seated at the table, pen in hand, a soiled ledger open, when Tom enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't mean to be nosy, y'understand. I just got to have certain information. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching him) Joad. Tom Joad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (writing) How many of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is seen in front of its camp site as the Joads descend.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How 'bout it, Uncle John? Gotta pitch this tent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (groggy with sleep) I'm a-comin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't look so good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *ain't* so good, but--I'm a-comin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As he exits we see the GOVERNMENT CAMP, with Tom coming out of the shack, amazement still on his face. As he walks slowly down the main camp street we share the revelation of the place to him. It is nearly daylight. Roosters crow in the distance. The street is neat and orderly in a military way, its cleanliness in sharp contrast to anything he has known before. Inside the tents people are stirring. In front of one tent a woman is cooking breakfast. A baby is in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he walks on, Tom draws a breath of exultation. As he moves on, looking around, we see the EXTERIOR OF SANITARY UNIT NO. 4, a cheap frame building the purpose of which is pretty obvious. Ruthie, warily alert lest she be caught, is peering in the door. She looks a long time and then she runs out of the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Camp site costs a dollar a week, but you can work it out, carrying garbage, keeping the camp clean--stuff like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll work it out. What's this committee you talkin' about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got five sanitary units. Each one elects a central committee man. They make the laws, an' what they say goes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you aimin' to tell me that the fellas that run this camp is jus' fellas--campin' here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the way it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) An' you say no cops?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) No cop can come in here without a warrant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (marveling) I can't hardly believe it. Camp I was in once, they burned it out--the deputies an' some of them poolroom fellas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They don't get in here. Sometimes the boys patrol the fences, especially dance nights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got dances too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got the best dances in the county every Saturday night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, who runs this place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Government.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why ain't they more like it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shortly) *You* find out, I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything like work aroun' here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't promise you that, but there'll be a licensed agent here tomorrow mornin', if you want to talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaving) Ma's shore gonna like it here. She ain't been treated decent for a long time.

dialogue.raw_text: (as Tom is at the door) That cut you got?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better take care of it. Store manager'll give you some stuff for it in the morning. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good mornin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mornin'.

direction.raw_text: is seen asleep in a quilt on the ground when Ruthie enters and rousts him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stumbles after her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in an excited whisper) Git up. I got sump'n to show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sleepily) Whatsa matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tugging him) It's them white things, made outa dish-stuff, like in the catalogues!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 4. Ruthie is putting on a bold front as she leads Winfield into sight but she is still alert for interference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He follows her into the unit, big-eyed with excitement and apprehension. There is a silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is the sound of a toilet flushing. It is a cheap toilet and it is a loud flush which eventually ends in a long refilling of the tank just as loudly. There is a paralyzed silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrified, Winfield comes dashing out of the unit but Ruthie grabs him just outside the door. Beginning to cry, he struggles to get away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods quickly. Then Ruthie begins to walk away with what she fancies is an innocent, nonchalant stroll, yawning casually. Sniffling a little, Winfield mimics her, a very innocent walk and yawn indeed. The scene dissolves to a DITCH. Alongside the ditch are some lengths of concrete pipe. Tom and the two Wallaces are in the ditch, Tom and Tim picking, Wilkie shoveling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Thomas, the farmer, a stock man wearing a paper sun helmet, enters. His face is worried as he squats down beside the ditch. What he has come to say has taken some effort and he is still uncertain and annoyed. The men stop work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shake hands. The scene dissolves to the GATE TO THE CAMP, at night. It is Saturday evening, the night of the dance. Glaring electric lights hang over the open gate. Parked jalopies line the highway as the invited guests, small farmers and migrants from other camps and their families, arrive to be greeted and checked by a committee of three men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is an air of eager anticipation, of gay celebration, and everyone is in his or her best--the men in clean washed overalls, clean shirts, some with ties, their hair damp and slicked down, the women in their nicest. Through the gate, inside the camp, can be seen the outdoor dance floor, brightly lighted, with the camp musicians already tuning up, and around the dance floor scores of wide-eyed children.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE EXTERIOR OF SANITARY UNIT NO

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. Ain't nobody gonna say anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Won't they ketch us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Them's where you wash your han's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's these?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncertainly) Well, I reckon you *stan'* in them little rooms--an' water come down outa that there little jigger up there--take a bath!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) Jes' like in the catalogues, ain't they!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly) I seen 'em b'fore you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in alarm) Now don't you go monk'ing--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you done it! You busted it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fiercely) Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weeping) I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lissen. You done busted it. You hear? (They listen to the refilling of the tank) But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't-- (craftily) --if you won't tell what *I* done!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exulting) If this don't feel good!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chuckling) Wait'll about 'leven o'clock, see how good she feels then!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems like a nice frien'ly fella to work for, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lotta these little farmers mighty nice fellas. Trouble is they're little, they ain't got much say-so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shore looks like my lucky day, anyway. Gettin' some work at las'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lissen here. Maybe I'm talkin' myself outa my farm, but I like you fellas, so I'm gonna tell you. You live in that gov'ment camp, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffening) Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you have dances every Saturday night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) We sure do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, look out next Saturday night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly tense) What you mean? I belong to the central committee. I got to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you ever tell I told.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Well, the association don't like the government camps. Can't get a deputy in there. Can't arrest a man without a warrant. But if there was a big fight, and maybe shooting--a bunch of deputies could go in and clean out the camp. (Unfolding a newspaper) Like last night. Lissen. "Citizens, angered at red agitators, burn another squatters' camp, warn agitators to get out of the county."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sick of the expression) Listen. What *is* these reds? Ever'time you turn aroun' somebody sayin' somebody else's a red. What is these reds, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chuckling) Well, I tell you. They was a fella up the country named King--got about 30,000 acres an' a cannery an' a winery--an' he's all a time talkin' about reds. Drivin' the country to ruin, he says. Got to git rid of 'em, he says. Well, they was a young fella jus' come out an' he was listenin one day. He kinda scratched his head an' he says, "Mr. King, what *is* these reds you all a time talkin' about?" Well, sir, Mr. King says, "Young man, a red is any fella that wants thirty cents a hour when I'm payin' twenty-five."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fretfully) I ain't talkin' about that one way or the other. All I'm saying is that there's going to be a fight in the camp Saturday night. And there's going to be deputies ready to go in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why? Those fellas ain't botherin' nobody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you why. Those folks in to being treated like humans. Suppose the Government closes its camps. Suppose too many people pass through 'em. Well, when those people go back to the squatters' camps they'll be hard to handle. (Wiping his brow) Go on back to work now. Maybe I've talked myself into trouble, but you're folks like us, and I like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (extending his hand) Nobody won't know who tol'. We thank you. (Grimly) An' they ain't gonna be no fight, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ev'nin', ma'am. Who'd you say invited you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mister an' Mizz Clark, they ast us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. Come right in, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: we see Wilkie and a dark- complexioned man named Jule standing among a group inside watching the arrivals. They watch sharply, eyeing everyone, listening to every credential. As his employer, Thomas, comes through the gate with his wife, Wilkie grins and greets him with a handshake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the DANCE FLOOR, and after three pats of the foot, to get the tempo, the home talent dance orchestra swings into music.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INSIDE THE GATE TO THE CAMP,

dialogue.raw_text: Hidy, Mr. Thomas. Hidy, Mizz Thomas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto voce) You watching out, ain't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Don't you worry. Ain't gonna be no trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you know what you're talking about. (He moves away, Wilkie grinning after him)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rosasharn dressed in her nicest, sits gripping her hands together, the music seeming to bring her to the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drying her hands, Ma sits beside Rosasharn and takes her in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smiling mysteriously, Ma fishes in a pocket in her dress and brings out the envelope of her treasures. From it she produces the earrings and holds them up in front of Rosasharn's wide eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They smile at each other, proud in the luxury of ornaments. Down the road from the GATE a touring car with six men pulls of the pavement and stops. Three men get out. They are bareheaded and dressed similar to the other migrants. They stroll down the highway toward the gate. The other men, deputies, sit watching them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ma... (Ma turns from drying dishes) Ma, I--I can't go to the dance. I jus' can't Ma. I can't hardly stan' it, with Connie not here--an' me this way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to cheer her) Why, honey, it makes folks happy to see a girl that way--makes folks sort of giggly an' happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (miserably) I can't he'p it, Ma. It don't make *me* giggly an' happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tenderly) You an' me's goin' together--jus' you an' me. We're a-goin' to that dance an' we're a-goin' to jus' set an' watch. If anybody says to come dance--why I'll say you're poorly. But you an' me, we're gonna hear the music an' see the fun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An' you won't let nobody touch me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No--an' look what I got for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) I used to wear these--when your pa come callin' on me. (Then as she puts them on Rosasharn's ears) You'll look pretty in 'em tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The three men from the touring car are at the gate. Wilkie and Jule watch them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three men stroll past Wilkie and Jule, whose eyes follow them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilkie moves after them. We see the DANCE FLOOR. The musicians are at it and the fiddler is calling turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well in front, among the older folks and children who surround the floor, are Ma and Rosasharn, clinging close. A young man stops in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Rosasharn's eyes drop. Ma bends toward her, a shy smile on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three men stroll into sight and stand watching the dancing. One glances at Ma and Rosasharn but does not speak. Ma has smiled back at him.

dialogue.raw_text: They tell me you're half Injun. You look all Injun to me.

dialogue.raw_text: Swing your ladies an' a dol ce do. Join han's roun' an' away we go! Swing to the right an' a swing to the lef'. Break, now break--back to back!

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you wouldn't think it, but your pa was as nice a dancer as I ever seen, when he was young. (With a little sigh) Kinda makes me think a ol' times.

direction.raw_text: are seen; removed somewhat from the dance floor they are peering in the direction of the three men.

direction.raw_text: We find ourselves INSIDE TIM WALLACE'S TENT.  The five members of the central committee, Tim Wallace, chairman, look grave as a 15-year-old boy reports.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a grim pause at this news. Tim's eyes go hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilkie makes a mocking military salute as he and Tom exit. The committee men look worriedly after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In front of the JOAD TENT, dressed to kill, is Al, ready for the festivities. He wears a tight-fitting wool suit, a tie on his shirt, yellow shoes, and his hair is damp and slicked down. He rubs his hands together in anticipation as he strolls in the direction of the dance floor. At ANOTHER TENT, a blonde girl sits on a box as Al enters. Casually he throws open his coat, revealing a vivid striped shirt. This is designed to stun his quarry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fat woman thrusts her head out of the tent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shrugging, Al winks at the girl and moves on, stepping and moving his shoulders and snapping his fingers in time to the music, a very gay fellow indeed. The blonde girl's eyes follow him. Then she turns and glances cautiously toward the tent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I seen 'em before. Worked at Gregorio's with 'em. But I never ast 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Awright. Keep your eye on 'em. Jus' keep 'em in sight, that's all. (He moves quickly away)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I seen 'em, Mr. Wallace. A car with six men parked down by the euc'lyptus tree an' one with three men on the main road. They got guns, too. I seen 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Willie. You done good. (As Willie exits) Well, it looks like the fat's in the far this time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) What them deppities want to hurt the camp for? How come they can't leave us be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What we oughta do, we oughta git us some pickhandles an'--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) No!  That's what they want. No sir. If they can git a fight goin', then they can run in the cops an' say we ain't orderly-- (He stops as Wilkie enters followed by Tom)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're here. We got 'em spotted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Tom) You sure you got ever'thing ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Ain't gonna be no trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worriedly) You ain't to hurt them fellas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) You don't have to worry. We got ever'thing arranged. Maybe nobody'll even see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just don't use no stick nor no knife, no piece a arn. An' if you got to sock 'em, sock 'em where they won't bleed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Awright. An' if she gets outa han', I'll be in the right han' corner, this side the dance floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blandly) Ain't gonna get outa han'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mighty sure a themselves, looks like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I hope, I hope they don't kill nobody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gonna dance tonight? (The girl ostentatiously ignores him) I can waltz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aloofly) That's nothin'--anybody can waltz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Not like me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You git right along! This here girl's spoke for. She's gonna be married, an' her man's a-comin' for her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: we see Ma and Rosasharn as Tom enters and stands between them. This is during a pause between dances and only a few couples stand on the floor waiting for the music to begin again. We also see the three men very casually looking around--but no more casual looking than Wilkie, standing just behind them, idly whistling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music starts again, once more the dancers move onto the dance floor. The three men exchange a glance and step casually to the edge of the dancing space, one in the lead. They survey the scene, but for the moment make no further move. The atmosphere is tense.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) She's gettin' prettier, Ma.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Rosasharn hides her face) Girl with a baby *always* gets prettier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Excuse me, Ma. (He moves quietly out of the scene, toward the three men)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: taking the blonde girl's hand, steps onto the dance floor. Encircling her waist, they begin to dance. They are a smooth, rhythmic couple who move as one being.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment the leader of the three men (the other two directly behind him) enters the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the three men a solid wall of migrants are closing in quietly, Tom and Wilkie in the middle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His fist goes back, his left hand reaches for Al's collar. At the same instant Tom grabs him, Wilkie claps his hand over the leader's mouth, at least fifteen other men have similarly collard the other two invaders, and they are all lifted bodily. There is not a sound as the three men, held in iron grips, are whisked from the dance floor and into the crowd. Two touring cars have stopped in front of the closed GATE and the deputies have drawn guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the deputies, puzzled and uncertain, look toward the DANCE FLOOR, we see the music, the dancing, the gaiety continuing as if nothing had happened.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you said anybody can waltz... How'm *I* doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't hold me so tight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tongue-in-cheek) Why, I ain't hardly touchin' you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squirming) You're *ticklin' me!*
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing her still closer) That comes from not holdin' you tight *enough.*
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (complaining but loving it) Now I can't breathe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll dance with this girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) You an' who else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't gimme no argament-- (A shrill whistle sounds in the distance) --you little--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open up! We hear you got a riot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Riot? I don't see no riot. Who're you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deputy sheriffs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a warrant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't need a warrant if it's a riot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know what you gonna do about it, because I don't hear no riot an' I don't see no riot, an' what's more I don't believe they *is* no riot. (Waving toward the dance floor) Look for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at night, several hours later: the tent is black, Tom strikes a match. From a piece of wood on the ground or floor he selects one from several cigarette butts and lights it. While he is doing so, he lifts his head suddenly, and listens. In the CAMP STREET we catch sight of legs walking, the ground lighted from a flashlight. Two pairs of the legs wear state policemen's leather leggings. The third pair are the caretaker's. They stop behind a car. The flashlight plays on the license plate. One of the state cops leans down to copy the license number in a booklet. Then they move on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has lifted the edge of the tent a trifle, enough to see out by flattening his head on the floor. The LEGS are now seen at the Joad jalopy. The light is on the license plate. The cop leans over and copies the number. They move on.
direction.name: direction
